results.title: Ancient Paestum : city of the Greeks and Romans
results.brief_description: In the ancient city of Paestum, in southern Italy, archaeologists have discovered remnants of a civilization founded by the Greeks in the 6th century B.C. and later dominated by the Romans. Shows the plan of the city and its buildings, many in the finest Doric tradition and in an excellent state of preservation. As well as the sculpture and ceramic work, artifacts and other relics of an ancient Greek and Roman culture.

results.title: Ancient Mesopotamia
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and John Smart
results.brief_description: The contributions of the Sumerians, Semites, Babylonians and Assyrians who occupied the Tigris-Euphrates Valley are depicted against authentic locales that include Babylon, Ur and Nineveh. These people were first to use the arch and the wheel. They developed a code of laws, a system of writing and military science - all of which have become a part of Western civilization. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Ancient Greece
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and David A. Smart
results.brief_description: An introduction to life in Greece in 500 B.C. showing glimpses of the ancient cities of Greece as they now stand in ruin and as they would appear in restoration. Architecture, art, drama, and athletics are considered, and the major contributions Greece has made to philosophy, science, mathematics and government are listed. Suitable for upper primary school and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Ancient Egypt
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and David A. Smart
results.brief_description: An introduction to the study of ancient Egypt showing the contributions to art, agriculture, writing and science. Considers three spheres in which the Egyptian civilization has contributed to Western culture; the development of agriculture, and the idea of community living; discoveries in the arts and sciences such as the use of mud bricks and the use of a calendar; the evolution of religion through the Egyptian practice of polytheism. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Ancient chinese paintings in America
results.creator_credit: China Institute in America, Harmon Foundation and Wan-go Wen
results.brief_description: Produced by the Harmon Foundation, USA, this film uses selected examples from the Chinese collections in three leading American museums. Mr. Wango Weng presents a survey of the history of chinese painting, and the representative art of each dynasty is shown.

results.title: Ancient art in Norway
results.brief_description: A survey of Norwegian art from ancient times to the Christian era. From rock paintings of fish, animals, people, vegetation and ships we follow the development and influences on art forms both domestic and public. Fine examples from all areas and ages are shown.
results.description: A survey of Norwegian art from ancient times to the Christian era. From rock paintings of fish, animals, people, vegetation and ships we follow the development and influences on art forms both domestic and public. Fine examples from all areas and ages are shown.

results.title: Anchors aweigh
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Joe Pasternak and George Sidney
results.brief_description: There are many moments of stunning virtuosity in George Sidney’s exuberant musical entertainment “Anchors Aweigh”. One of the most wonderful of all MGM’s musicals, it is set in Los Angeles and Hollywood. Isobel Lennart’s witty screenplay is about two sailors on leave - Gene Kelly and Frank Sinatra - and their involvement with a Hollywood extra - Kathryn Grayson - whom they want to help become a musical star. The songs include “All of a Sudden my Heart Sings”, “Jealousy”, “All of a Sudden my Heart Sings”, “I Fall in Love too Easily” and “What Makes the Sunset”. Rated: G

results.title: Anchor man
results.brief_description: Describes how the Royal Australian Navy trains reservists as part-time sailors. They train once a week and receive two weeks full time training at sea where they learn the skills needed to man a Defense craft. They would back up the permanent servicemen in the event of hostile action. No other credits available.

results.title: Anatomy of violence
results.creator_credit: National Educational Television and Peter F. Davis
results.brief_description: This film presents several speeches on the relationship of violence to social reform. The speakers who took part in a Congress on the Dialectics of Liberation, held in London and sponsored by the Institute of Phenomenological Studies, include: Allen Ginsberg (poet), Paul Goodman (editor of “Liberation” magazine), Herbert Marcuse (Professor of Philosophy, University of California) and Stokely Carmichael (former Chairman Student Non-violent Co-ordinating Committee). and others. Following the speeches two social scientists evaluated the conference.
